titleStmt.title: George Daly v. J.H. McGraw. Petition

bibl.title: George Daly v. J.H. McGraw. Petition
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

div1.ab: In the District Court of the Third Judicial District of Washington Territory, holding terms at Seattle, King County, W.T.
In the m atter of the application of George R. Daly for Writ of Habeas Corpus. | Petition.
To the Honorable Roger S. Greene of said Court, and Chief Justice of Washington Territory.
The petition of George R. Daly respectfully shows:
div1.p:
That he is imprisioned and restrained of his liberty at the City of Seattle in the County of King, in the county jail of said county, by J.H. McGraw, Sheriff of said County of King; that he is not imprisioned under and by virtue of any commitment upon any process issued on any final judgement of a court of competent jurisdiction, nor for any conptempt of court, officer, or body having authority in the premises to commit; nor upon any warrant issued from the district court upon an indictment or information; that the cause of pretence of such imprisionment according to the best knowledge and belief of your petitioner, is aas follows, to wit: a warrant issued outof a court of the Justice of the Peace in Seattle Precinct in said City of Seattle, by T.H. Cann, one of the Justices of the Peace in and for said precinct, on the 11th day of March 1884, directed to the Sheriff or any Constable of said County, directing and commanding him to apprehend forthwith the petitioner which said warrant was issued upon an information filed in said Justice Court and sworn before said T.H. Cann, Justice aforesaid, by one J.H. Woolery, on the 10th day of March 1884 charging the peitioner with having committed the crime of Grand Larceny on the day of 1884, by feloniously stealing a horse in
in said state of Oregon. In which information it is stated that the complaint therein contained is made from information received by telegram, recieved that date. That the pretended cause for the future further continuance of said imprisionement and restraint of petitioners liberty is a warrant issued out of the aforesaid Justices Court by the said T.H. Cann, Justice of the Peace on the 13th day of March 1884, Directed to the sheriff or anhy constable of said county, directing and commanding him forthwith to apprehend petitioner, which said warrant was issued upon an information filed in said Justice Court and sworn to before T.H. Cann, Justice aforesaid by one Daniel Sprague, on the 13th day of March 1884, charging the petitioner with having committed the crime of Grand Larceny on or about the fifth day of March 1884 in the State of Oregon, by feloniously stealing taking and leading away one horse of the value of fifty dollars, the property of one William Daly. That the said John H. McGraw now restrains the liberty of said Petitioner under and by pretence of the pretended authority given by said warrant hereinbefore mentioned. That hereto annexed and m arked respectively "A" and "B" are true copies of the warrants and informations by which the said John H. McGraw claims to detain your Petitioner. That your petitioner has heretofore repeatedly since the time of his arrest and detention demanded to be given the privilege of an immediate hearing and examination upon the charges alleged in said informations, but without just cause has been and ow is reused any hearing or examination upon said charge. That your petitioner is advised by John H. Mitchell, who resides at the city of Seattle, and is an attorney of this court, and his counsel herein, that such imprisonment is illegal, in that, there never was issued to said J.H. McGraw, Sheriff aforesaid any commitment by any authority of law or court authorized to issue the same or any mandate
requiring or directing him to imprison or restrain the liberty of the petitioner, and in that a reasonable time has elapsed since the arrest of the petitioner within which the hearing and examination could have been had upon the chargs a lleged in the said informations, nad the privilege o f, and right to, and immediate trial hearing and examination, or any examination whatever, had been wholly refused and denied to said petitioner.
Wherefore your petitioner applies for a writ of habeuas corpus for the purpose of inquiring into the cause of such imprisionment and of delievering him therefrom and discharging him from custody.
div1.ab: Dated at Seattle W.T. March 15th 1884 Geo R Daly
Territory of Washington County of King. | ss.
div1.p: George R. Daly being first duly sworn, on oath deposes and says: That he is the petitioner named in the above petition; had heard the same read, and believes the same to be true.
div1.ab: Subscribed and sworn to before me This 15th dat of March A.D. 1884 Juline A. Ceicle Notary public in and for King County, W.T.
No. 3748 In the District Court 3d Judicial District, holding terms at Seattle Washington Territory.
In the matter of the application of George R aly for a writ of Plaintiff Habeas Corpus
Filed March 16th 1884 James Seavey Clerk By James P Ludlow Deputy.
McNaught, Ferry, McNaught amperstand Mitchell. Attorneys for Petition
